messageBody:

On 28.4.2007 Paige Gabhart wrote:
> Why /should/ quikscript be adapatable to other languages?

There areseveral possible reasons for wanting to adapt QS to
languages other than English. The ones relevant to me (there
may be others relevant to other people) are:

- QS has an advantage over traditional orthography not only
in terms of mapping signs to phonemes of the English
language, but it is also the case that its signs have an
ergonomic advantage over the Latin alphabet, offering some
of the advantages of shorthand while avoiding its greatest
disadvantage, namely that while words written in shorthand
tend to 'crawl' or 'climb' upwards and/or downwards on the
page QS stays on the line like ordinary longhand. This is
not to say that QS can really compete with shorthand for
writing speed -- my guestimate being that full Senior QS
is about as quick as wholly unabbreviated shorthand, which
is still considerably quicker than ordinary longhand --,
but QS reading speed is considerably higher than for
shorthand, especially when reading what someone else has
written, and still the graphic simplification of the QS
letters allows for saving effort and time not only in
writing but also in reading, regardless of who has
written. In fact QS handwriting doesn't degrade as easily
and quickly nor as much as Latin handwriting, as all who
have written QS know, exactly because it's graphic shapes
are already optimized and don't need any further
simplification to save effort. Why should I deny myself
the gain in speed and tidiness offered by QS only because
I happen to be writing in any language other than English?

- There are other languages beside English which are beset
with overly complicated traditional orthographies. Among
European languages French, Faroese, German, Danish, Greek
and Russian may be mentioned, and in Asia there are Bangla
and Burmese, Tibetan -- which rivals and is similar to
English in complication --, and Japanese and the various
Chinese languages. To be sure one could devise phonemic
Latin scripts for these languages, but would them have to
forgo the graphic optimization offered by QS, devise
optimized letters very similar or identical to QS, but
with different mappings of sounds to shapes, or adapt QS
itself as nearly as possible. Mapping of the same shapes
to different sounds in alphabets based no the same
principle is a major annoyance for those who need to
switch between different alphabets, as anyone can testify
who has come from the Latin alphabet to Cyrillic cursive,
where shapes looking like "d g u n p m y r" map to /b d i
p r t u ja/, in comparison to which which mappings like "b
e c" to /v je s/ remain minor annoyances as they at least
remain within the range of similarity to the familiar.

- Switching alphabets when switching languages in the same
text may be annoying, especially when reading. I have some
knowledge of Gregg's shorthand for English, and I may gain
some knowledge of Russian shorthand, but to determine when
reading which of three systems a given squiggle represents
is an enormous waste of time, eyestrain and mental effort,
and therefore I prefer to adapt Swedish shorthand to
English and Russian, preserving a basic sameness even if
letter to sound matching may differ in details. Similarly
when mixing alphabets in longhand writing I find myself
underlining words written in the embedded alphabet, since
when reading it takes time and effort to decide whether an
isolated "p" shape is /p/ or /r/, or a string "can" is
/sap/ or /k&n/.

- Last but not least there may be gratification in the
exercise of adapting a script to another language which I
see no reason to deny those seeking it.
